snippet.title: Hospital celebrates 70 years in Nambour
snippet.content: IN 1947, private hospitals were few and far between. When Dr Jim Trotter and his colleagues were unable to get private patients into appropriate beds at existing hospitals, they took matters into their own hands. The doctors joined forces with nursing sisters Christine Oxley and Dorothy Ralston, and Nambour Selangor Private Hospital was born. Last week staff at the hospital celebrated the institution's 70th birthday, with the official event held on July 22. Chief Executive Officer at Nambour Selangor Private Hospital Sandra Moore said she was proud of the healthcare the team had continued to provide over the years. "Our staff are excellent here, they really are the backbone of our care to the community and are very passionate about what they do," she said. "(They) are quiet achievers, just out there caring for the community and making sure that when people are unwell and need healthcare, we are there for them. "There is such a camaraderie and connection to our patients and the community... if they can just do one thing to make their patients' journey a little better, that is what excites them. "Our 70th birthday is a wonderful opportunity to celebrate not only our success in providing healthcare but also to honour our forebears who had the vision to open a private hospital in Nambour which has continually provided a wide range of medical and surgical services, as well as an excellent Rehabilitation Unit." The team at the hospital celebrated the birthday by decorating various departments and wards with hospital memorabilia spanning over the ages, along with a special birthday party luncheon and cake. To mark the occasion, the surgical and medical wards at the hospital were also renamed to honour founding Nursing Sisters Christine Oxley and Dorothy Ralston in recognition of their contributions. "It is important to recognise your forebearers," Ms Moore said. "During the hospital's life we estimate that over 750,000 patients have been treated here at one time or another. "It's not always nice for people to be in hospital, because they are sick and away from family, but we are here and we are always happy to have them when and if they need us."
